                                           GWTC-3: Compact Binary Coalescences Observed by LIGO and Virgo during the
                                                           Second Part of the Third Observing Run

                    296
                        Department of Electrophysics, National Chiao Tung University, Hsinchu, Taiwan
                     297
                         Department of Physics, Rikkyo University, Toshima-ku, Tokyo 171-8501, Japan
                                                         (Dated: October 24, 2023)
                                                                                                                         11

                The third Gravitational-Wave Transient Catalog (GWTC-3) describes signals detected with Ad-
             vanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo up to the end of their third observing run. Updating the previous
             GWTC-2.1, we present candidate gravitational waves from compact binary coalescences during the
             second half of the third observing run (O3b) between 1 November 2019, 15:00 UTC and 27 March
             2020, 17:00 UTC. There are 35 compact binary coalescence candidates identified by at least one
             of our search algorithms with a probability of astrophysical origin pastro > 0.5. Of these, 18 were
             previously reported as low-latency public alerts, and 17 are reported here for the first time. Based
             upon estimates for the component masses, our O3b candidates with pastro > 0.5 are consistent
             with gravitational-wave signals from binary black holes or neutron star–black hole binaries, and
             we identify none from binary neutron stars. However, from the gravitational-wave data alone, we
             are not able to measure matter effects that distinguish whether the binary components are neutron
             stars or black holes. The range of inferred component masses is similar to that found with previous
             catalogs, but the O3b candidates include the first confident observations of neutron star–black hole
             binaries. Including the 35 candidates from O3b in addition to those from GWTC-2.1, GWTC-3
             contains 90 candidates found by our analysis with pastro > 0.5 across the first three observing runs.
             These observations of compact binary coalescences present an unprecedented view of the properties
             of black holes and neutron stars.

             PACS numbers: 04.80.Nn, 04.25.dg, 95.85.Sz, 97.80.-d, 04.30.Db, 04.30.Tv

                                                                                                                                             12

ber of GW candidates during O3 was enabled by the
                                                                                               O1 O2         O3a               O3b
improved sensitivity of the detector network. A con-
ventional measure of sensitivity is the binary neutron
star (BNS) inspiral range, which quantifies the average
                                                                                         100
distance at which a fiducial 1.4M⊙ + 1.4M⊙ BNS could




                                                                 Cumulative detections
be detected with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 8 [22–
24]. During O3b observations, the median BNS inspiral                                     80
ranges for LIGO Livingston, LIGO Hanford and Virgo
were 133 Mpc, 115 Mpc and 51 Mpc, respectively. In                                        60
Fig. 1, we show the growth in the number of candidates in
the LVK catalog across observing runs. Here, the search                                   40
sensitivity is quantified by the BNS time–volume, which
should be approximately proportional to the search sen-
sitivity to the overall astrophysical CBC population and                                  20
hence to the number of detections [3]. The BNS time–
volume is defined as the observing time multiplied by the                                  0
Euclidean sensitive volume for the detector network [24].                                  0.000       0.001     0.002     0.003     0.004
For O1 and O2, the observing time includes periods when                                            Effective BNS time–volume [Gpc3 yr]
at least two detectors were observing, and the Euclidean

   We begin with an overview of the status of the Ad-          tables of inferred source parameters.
vanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo detectors during O3b
(Sec. II), and then we review the properties and quality of
the data used in the analyses (Sec. III). We report the sig-
nificance of the candidates identified by template-based                                               II.   INSTRUMENTS
and minimally modeled search analyses, and we compare

harmonics.                                                     with GW data collection.

Figure 3. The BNS inspiral range [22–24] of the LIGO and Virgo detectors. Left: The range evolution during O3b. Each
data point corresponds to the median value of the range over a one-hour time segment. Right: Distributions of the range and
the median values for the entire duration of O3b; the data for Virgo are separately reported for the intervals before (I) and
after (II) 28 January 2020 to illustrate changes in the range following detector improvements. An improvement in squeezer
performance at LIGO Hanford is indicated at 2 January 2020.

   The dimensionless strain time series measured by the                                                             suspension systems, gathered while the detector is of-
LIGO and Virgo detectors are an input to the astrophys-                                                             fline (roughly once per week). An initial version of cali-
ical analyses. They are reconstructed from different out-                                                           brated strain data is produced in low latency throughout
put signals from the detectors and detailed modeling of                                                             an observing period, and the final calibration models are
the response of the detector [42, 45]. The reconstructed                                                            assembled after the completion of an observing period
strain time series are timestamped following Global Posi-                                                           where the detector configuration was stable [45, 53]. As
tioning System (GPS) time, taking into account both the                                                             needed, the GW strain data stream is then regenerated
delays introduced in the synchronized distributed-clock                                                             offline from the optical power variations and the con-
timing system and data conditioning along the data-                                                                 trol signals, and the systematic error estimate is updated
acquisition systems [46]. The detector responses are de-                                                            based on the model used for the offline strain reconstruc-
scribed as complex-valued frequency-dependent transfer                                                              tion.
functions [42, 47]. Some control-system model param-                                                                   The best available strain data for each detector have

candidate reported in Table XVI.                                While the CBC pipelines consider all possible (double or
                                                                triple) detector combinations to form coincident triggers,

       IV.   CANDIDATE IDENTIFICATION                           other significant difference across pipelines is the data
                                                                baseline used to assign FARs to candidates. The FAR is
                                                                used as a measure of significance, and defines how reg-
   Identification of candidates and assessment of their sig-
                                                                ularly we would expect to see a noise (nonastrophysical
nificance relative to the background of detector noise is
                                                                background) trigger with the same, or higher, ranking
the first step in extracting catalog results. This is fol-
                                                                statistic as the candidate. GstLAL compares candidates
lowed by detailed analyses to estimate source properties

(Sec. V) and reconstruct waveforms (Sec. VI). We use
                                                                cWB, MBTA and PyCBC use local background from a
multiple search algorithms to identify potential GW can-
                                                                typical time span of one to a few weeks. All pipelines esti-
didates in our data. Searches are performed at two dif-
                                                                mate background distributions empirically from the O3b
ferent latencies: online searches are run in near-real time
                                                                data. Further technical details of the search algorithms
as data are collected, and offline searches are completed
                                                                are given in Appendix D.
later, using the final calibrated and cleaned dataset. The
online analyses allow for the rapid release of public alerts
associated with candidates to enable the search for mul-
                                                                 A.   Modeled search analyses for transient sources
timessenger counterparts, as described in Appendix A.
The offline analyses benefit from improved background
statistics, extensive data calibration, vetting and condi-        The dedicated CBC search algorithms use matched fil-
tioning as described in Sec. III, and the ability to perform    tering [95, 96], identifying candidates by correlating the
more computationally expensive calculations to separate         data with templates. We use sets of templates, or banks,
signals from background given the relaxation of latency         that provide a discrete sampling of the parameter space
requirements. Because of these factors, the offline anal-       defined by the binary component masses m1 and m2 (the
yses are more sensitive than the online analyses. The           primary and secondary masses, defining m1 ≥ m2 ), and
increased sensitivity of the offline analyses means that        the corresponding dimensionless spins ⃗ χ1 and ⃗χ2 .
differences in the final candidate list compared to the on-       The signals expected from CBCs are well characterized
line results are expected. While the lowest FAR candi-          by combinations of the binary component parameters.
dates are expected to remain significant, candidates with       To leading order, the phase evolution during inspiral of
a higher FAR (e.g., near the threshold for public low-          a binary is determined by the chirp mass [97, 98],
latency alerts) are more likely to have changes in signif-
icance when reevaluated offline, causing them to move                                       (m1 m2 )3/5
                                                                                   M=                    .              (1)
above or below the corresponding threshold for inclusion                                   (m1 + m2 )1/5
in this catalog. The differences between the online and
offline search results are further discussed in Sec. IV D 1.    We also use the total mass M = m1 + m2 , and the mass

performed after the end of O3b.                                 dimensionless component spin ⃗    χi = cS ⃗i /(Gm2 ), where

transient signals without assuming a waveform template

plate Analysis (MBTA) [82, 83] and PyCBC [23, 84–88],           where L̂N is the unit vector in the direction of the Newto-
and one that searches for transient signals with minimal        nian orbital angular momentum. In the modeled search
assumptions about sources, cWB [60, 89, 90]. The four           analyses, the spins are assumed to be parallel to L̂N .
pipelines used offline were also operated in online config-       The banks cover systems with total masses, redshifted
urations, along with the waveform-based Summed Par-             to the detector frame [101], ranging from a minimum

to identify candidate GW signals in low latency. Of the         200M⊙ (MBTA), 500M⊙ (PyCBC) or 758M⊙ (GstLAL).
four pipelines, cWB, GstLAL, and PyCBC were used for            The minimum binary component mass is 1M⊙ . Searches

data, whereas MBTA was first used for offline analysis of       been completed in complementary analyses [27, 102–106].

The PyCBC pipeline performs two search analyses. The          the expected frequency range of BBH signals. The anal-
first is an analysis encompassing a wide parameter space,     ysis is further split into two configurations that target
allowing detection of many different types of CBC sys-        high-mass (central frequency fc < 80 Hz) and low-mass
tems, which we refer to as the PyCBC-broad analysis. In       (fc > 80 Hz) BBH systems [111]. Technical details of the
addition to this broad analysis, PyCBC is also used in a      cWB analysis are given in Appendix D 5.
different configuration, which we refer to as the PyCBC-
BBH analysis: this analysis is restricted to BBH systems
with total masses between 10M⊙ and 500M⊙ , mass ra-                   C.   Probability of astrophysical origin
tios in the range 1/3 ≤ q ≤ 1, and component masses in
the range 5M⊙ ≤ m1 ≤ 350M⊙ and m2 ≥ 5M⊙ . This                   Our primary criterion for selecting candidates for fur-
PyCBC-BBH analysis is designed to have higher sensi-          ther study is the probability of astrophysical origin pastro .

the search of O3a [4].                                        the strongly differing rates of detectable signals from

duces a time series of SNR values for each detector, and      ability of being an astrophysical signal will naturally be

sidered further in the analysis. This SNR threshold is        well suited for selecting candidates from a catalog con-

varying across the parameter space, for MBTA. MBTA            ities. As the true alarm rate increases with improved
and PyCBC assign a significance to triggers found with        sensitivity, the FAR needed for a candidate to reach a

   The cWB pipeline searches for generic, short transient     cal sources, and the detectors’ and analysis’ sensitivity,
signals across a network of GW detectors [60, 107–110].       which is calculated using simulated signals. The number
It provides rapid detection of GW transient signals with      of background triggers is derived from the same back-
its online instance, and signal reconstructions and esti-     ground distribution used to estimate FAR by the search
mates of their significance with the version that runs of-    analyses.
fline on the final dataset. Designed to operate without a        As we cannot provide full source-parameter estimates
specific waveform model, cWB identifies coherent excess       for all candidates with FAR < 2.0 day−1 , we instead esti-
power in multiresolution time–frequency representations       mate the probability to originate from different categories
of the detector strain data. The SNR for each detec-          of binary source (BNS, NSBH and BBH). These proba-
tor is estimated from the reconstructed waveforms, and        bilities are estimated by each pipeline separately and rely
the network SNR is calculated by combining the SNRs           primarily on the template masses with which triggers are
from the individual detectors. The cWB search analy-          recovered (see Appendix D 7 for more details). For cal-
ses and reconstructions reported in this catalog primar-      culating pastro , all triggers from the cWB analysis are
ily target BBH sources and are limited to the 16 Hz–          assumed to be from BBH sources as cWB has a reduced
512 Hz range [60] to boost computational efficiency given     sensitivity to other population types. The source classes

are defined in this calculation via an assumed boundary       icant candidates as our understanding of the population
at 3M⊙ : we consider any component with lower mass            evolves with further observations [118–120].
to be in the NS class and any component above as BH.
These classes do not necessarily reflect the true division
between NSs and BHs. The maximum mass of NSs is                                  D.   Search results

Table I. Candidate GW signals. The time (UTC) of the signal is encoded in the name as GWYYMMDD hhmmss (e.g.,
GW200112 155838 occurred on 2020-01-12 at 15:58:38). The names of candidates not previously reported are given in bold.
The detectors observing at the merger time of the candidate are indicated using single-letter identifiers (e.g., H for LIGO
Hanford); these are not necessarily the same detectors that contributed triggers associated with the candidate. Where a
candidate was found with pastro above the threshold value of 0.5 by at least one analysis but below the threshold by others, we
include in italics the results from the other analyses, where available. A dash (–) indicates that a candidate was not found by
an analysis. The 2 candidates labeled with a dagger (†) were found only above threshold in a single detector with the GstLAL
analysis, and the FAR estimates were made using significant extrapolation of the background data, meaning that single-detector
candidates have higher uncertainty than coincident candidates. A conservative estimate of the FAR for these single-detector
candidates is one per live time of the analysis; this is ∼ 3.16 yr−1 for both LIGO Hanford and LIGO Livingston.
                                                                                                                       21

tended list of candidates with FAR < 2.0 day−1 is avail-            short-duration minimally modeled transients [31],
able from GWOSC [33], and discussed in Sec. IV D 5.                 but that analysis was uniformly carried out on the

                                                                    ger did not qualify because of its low coherence

pipelines will be largest for candidates with low SNR;               of pastro calculations to the assumed astrophysi-
thus, it is expected that such candidates may be identi-             cal population. For candidates at the edges of (or
fied by only a subset of pipelines. As methods used by               outside of) the confidently detected populations,
different pipelines will be more or less effective in sup-           like GW191219 163120, there may be large, model-
pressing specific types of noise artifacts, and the sensitiv-        dependent systematic uncertainties in pastro . Fu-
ity of different pipelines will have different dependencies          ture observations will reduce the uncertainty in the
on binary signal parameters, combining information from              rate of similar mergers, and thus enable us to better
multiple pipelines should lead to a greater understanding            quantify the origin of GW191219 163120.
of the population of astrophysical sources [122–124].

by other pipelines:                                                Despite its high SNR, GW200129 065458 was identi-

   • The GstLAL analysis found 2 unique candidates              specific set of circumstances. A data-quality issue in

      4.   Marginal candidates and GW200105 162426              multidetector triggers, an extended background estimate
                                                                can be obtained by constructing unphysical coincidences
   In Table II we report the marginal candidates that are       between triggers in different detectors. Consequently, for
found by each analysis below a FAR threshold of 2.0 yr−1        single-detector candidates like GW200105 162426 that lie
but do not satisfy the pastro threshold for inclusion in Ta-    outside the background noise distribution, the FAR esti-
ble I. The naming of these marginal candidates follows          mation relies on an extrapolation. For triggers in the tail
the same YYMMDD hhmmss format as that described                 of the background distribution, this extrapolation comes
for the candidates of Table I, except omitting the GW           with uncertainty that impacts the estimated FAR, and
prefix for the two candidates found to be caused by in-         this uncertainty also propagates to the noise distribution
strumental artifacts; for the other marginal candidates,        used in the calculation of pastro [3, 8].
we cannot exclude the possibility that they are quiet GW           Additionally, the pastro estimation for NSBH sources
signals.                                                        depends on the foreground distribution of ranking statis-
   The      marginal        candidates      200121 031748,      tics as well as their merger rate. The former is subject
200214 224526 and 200219 201407 were found to                   to uncertainties coming from a lack of knowledge of the
be likely caused by instrument artifacts. At the time           NSBH population, while the latter has large error bars
of 200121 031748, LIGO Hanford data contain excess              due to a paucity of high-significance NSBH detections
power consistent with a blip glitch, a common glitch            (order ∼ 1). Such uncertainties on pastro have a signifi-
in LIGO detector data [63, 125]. At the time of                 cant impact on marginal candidates whose pastro values
200214 224526, LIGO Livingston data contained signif-           hover around 0.5. As a consequence, the moderate pastro
icant excess noise due to fast scattering, while LIGO           value assigned at this time to GW200105 162426 does
Hanford data showed evidence for a weak scattering              not allow us to draw a firm conclusion on its origin. Fu-
arch; this candidate was further examined in the search         ture observations will likely shed more light on the true
for IMBH binaries [26], and is discussed in Appendix F.         provenance of this and similar candidates.
At the time of 200219 201407, LIGO Hanford data are
highly nonstationary, with multiple loud glitches visible
within 1 s of the candidate time.                                               5.    Subthreshold candidates

                                                                                                  Sensitive hypervolume hV T i [Gpc yr]


Figure 6. Sensitive hypervolume ⟨V T ⟩ from O3b for the various searches with pastro > 0.5 at the assessed points in the mass
parameter space. The Any results come from calculating the sensitive hypervolume for injections found by at least one search
analysis. The plotted points correspond to the central points of the log-normal distributions (with widths 0.1) used for the
calculation of ⟨V T ⟩. Each point is marked by a pie chart, where the darker portion represents the fraction of the Any ⟨V T ⟩
recovered. The colour of the darker portion corresponds to the value of the sensitive ⟨V T ⟩, as given by the scale bar. The
values displayed are the same as those given in Table III.

GW200201 203549          HLV         –          –         –          1.4      9.0       0.12        850             8 .9   < 0 .01       1 .0 × 10 3       8 .3       < 0 .01

GW200311 103121          HL          –          –         –          110      9 .0     < 0 .01      1.3             9.0     0.03            1.3            9.2         0.19




Table II. Marginal candidates found by the various analyses. The candidates in this table have a FAR below a threshold of
2.0 yr−1 in at least one analysis, but were not found with pastro that meets our threshold for Table I (pastro > 0.5 from a
search analysis, with the additional requirement that cWB candidates have a counterpart from a matched-filter analysis). The
probability of astrophysical origin pastro quoted (i) assumes a CBC source, which may not always be applicable for candidates
identified by the minimally modeled cWB analysis, and (ii) do not factor in data-quality information that was not used by
the search algorithms. Further information on the cWB-only candidate 200214 224526 is available in Appendix F. Detector-
identifying letters are the same as given in Table I. The instruments for each candidate are the ones which were operating at the
time of the trigger, and are not necessarily the same as those which participated in the detection. The candidates are named
according to the same convention as in Table I except that here we omit the GW prefix for the candidates found to be likely
caused by instrumental artifacts, indicated with an asterisk (∗). Where a candidate was seen below the FAR threshold in at
least one analysis but above threshold in others, we include in italics the information on that trigger from the other analyses as
well where available. As in Table I, the dagger (†) indicates a candidate found by a single detector with the GstLAL analysis.

Table III. Sensitive hypervolume from O3b for the various search analyses with pastro > 0.5 at the assessed points in the mass
parameter space. The Any results come from calculating the sensitive hypervolume for injections found by at least one search
analysis. For each set of binary masses, the given values are the central points of a log-normal distribution with width 0.1. For
some regions and analyses, few injections were recovered such that the sensitive hypervolume cannot be accurately estimated;
these cases are indicated by a dash (–). As an example of this, the PyCBC-BBH and cWB analyses analyzed only injections
in the designated BBH set, and so no injections were found in the BNS or NSBH regions. The injected population is described
in Appendix D 7.

                                  M [M ]                          q              χeff              χp              DL [Gpc]

Figure 7. Marginal probability distributions for the source chirp mass M, mass ratio q, effective inspiral spin χeff , effective
precession spin χp and luminosity distance DL for O3b candidates with pastro > 0.5 plus GW200105 162426. The colored
upper half of the plot shows the marginal posterior distributions, and the white lower half of the plot shows the marginal prior
distributions. The vertical extent of each colored region is proportional to one-dimensional marginal probability distribution
at a given parameter value for the corresponding candidate. We highlight with italics GW200105 162426 as it has pastro < 0.5,
as well as GW191219 163120 because of significant uncertainty in its pastro and because it has significant posterior support
outside of mass ratios where the waveform models have been calibrated. Results for GW200308 173609 and GW200322 091133
include a low-likelihood mode at large distances and high masses. Colors correspond to the date of observation.

Table IV. Median and 90% symmetric credible intervals for selected source parameters, and the 90% credible area for the sky
localization for O3b candidates with pastro > 0.5 plus GW200105 162426. We highlight with italics GW200105 162426 as it has
pastro < 0.5, as well as GW191219 163120 because of significant uncertainty in its pastro and because it has significant posterior
support outside of mass ratios where the waveform models have been calibrated. An asterisk (∗) is used to indicate candidates
for which the posterior distributions are dominated by potentially unphysical, low-likelihood modes at large distances and
high masses, and are particularly prior sensitive. The columns show source total mass M , chirp mass M, component masses
mi , effective inspiral spin χeff , luminosity distance DL , redshift z, final mass Mf , final spin χf , sky localization ∆Ω and the
network matched-filter SNR. All quoted results are calculated using BBH waveform models; values come from averaging
IMRPhenomXPHM and SEOBNRv4PHM results, except for the SNR (which is given for IMRPhenomXPHM because the RIFT analysis
used for SEOBNRv4PHM does not output this quantity).
                                                                                                                        30

vanishing) signal from a higher-mass, more-distant                   1.   Masses of sources with strictly m2 > 3M⊙ :
source. However, this support for high masses and large                           Unambiguous BBHs
distances is driven by our choice of prior, which was
not designed to model the astrophysical population of             The mass combination with greatest influence on a
sources. Therefore, we consider that the high-likelihood       CBC signal’s frequency evolution is the chirp mass

Figure 8. Credible-region contours for the inferred masses of the O3b candidates with pastro > 0.5 plus GW200105 162426.
Top: Results for the primary and secondary component masses m1 and m2 . The shaded areas indicate regions excluded
by the convention m1 ≥ m2 , and by the most extreme mass ratio considered in our analyses (detailed in Appendix E 3).
Bottom: Results for total mass M and mass ratio q. Each contour represents the 90% credible region for a different candidate.
Highlighted contours are for the NSBH candidates GW191219 163120, GW200105 162426 and GW200115 042309; the NSBH
or low-mass BBH candidate GW200210 092254; GW191204 171526, which has inferred χeff > 0; GW200225 060421, which has
85% probability that χeff < 0, and GW200220 061928, which probably has the most massive source of the O3b candidates. We
highlight with italics GW200105 162426 as it has pastro < 0.5, as well as GW191219 163120 because of significant uncertainty in
its pastro and because it has significant posterior support outside of mass ratios where the waveform models have been calibrated.
Results for GW200308 173609 and GW200322 091133 are indicated with dashed lines to highlight that these include a low-
likelihood mode at large distances and high masses, and are particularly prior sensitive. The dotted lines delineate regions
where the primary and secondary can have a mass below 3M⊙ . For the region above the m2 = 3M⊙ line, both objects in the
binary have masses above 3M⊙ .

                                               1.00

                                               0.75




               Effective inspiral spin χeff
                                               0.50

                                               0.25

                                               0.00

                                              −0.50

                                              −0.75

                                              −1.00
                                                      1   2   4      7    10        20          40        70   100
                                                                  Chirp mass M [M ]


Figure 9. Credible-region contours in the plane of chirp mass M and effective inspiral spin χeff for O3b candidates with
pastro > 0.5 plus GW200105 162426. Each contour represents the 90% credible region for a different candidate. Highlighted
contours are for the NSBH candidates GW191219 163120, GW200105 162426 and GW200115 042309; the NSBH or low-
mass BBH candidate GW200210 092254; GW191204 171526, which has inferred χeff > 0; GW200225 060421, which has 85%
probability that χeff < 0, and GW200220 061928, which probably has the most massive source of the O3b candidates. We
highlight with italics GW200105 162426 as it has pastro < 0.5, as well as GW191219 163120 because of significant uncertainty in
its pastro and because it has significant posterior support outside of mass ratios where the waveform models have been calibrated.
Results for GW200308 173609 and GW200322 091133 are indicated with dashed lines to highlight that these include a low-
likelihood mode at large distances and high masses, and are particularly prior sensitive.

                                                                    The spin orientations of a binary can provide clues to
                                                                 its formation channel [149, 232, 292–296]. Dynamically
                         B.   Spins                              assembled binaries would have no preferred spin orien-
                                                                 tation, and therefore are expected to have an isotropic
  Spins leave a relatively subtle imprint on the GW sig-         distribution of spin orientations (unless embedded in an
nal, and so they are more difficult to measure from ob-          environment like the disc of an active galactic nucleus
servations than the masses [13, 152–154, 170, 271–273].          where accretion or consecutive mergers can result in an
Typically, it is not possible to put strong constraints          anisotropic spin distribution [297–301]); on the other
on individual components’ spins, as the evolution of the         hand, binaries formed through isolated binary evolu-
system is primarily determined by mass-weighted com-             tion are typically expected to have nearly aligned spins,
binations of the two component spins [274–278]. How-             with moderate misalignments arising due to supernova
ever, when a binary has unequal masses it may also be            kicks [302–308]. Therefore, negative χeff or large χp
possible to constrain the primary spin because χ1 dom-           would be more common in dynamically formed binaries
inates the spin contributions to the signal. To reflect          than those formed through isolated evolution.
how the two spins influence the signal, we quote results            Most of the candidates in O3b are consistent

are placed on χp , so the posterior covers a significant frac-   Overall, the range of inferred χeff values matches the
tion of its prior range [3, 287, 288]. Since χp is weakly        range for previous LVK candidates [4] as well as can-
constrained, the shape of the χp prior often dominates           didates from non-LVK analyses (when adopting compa-
the posterior. The χp prior tends to zero at χp = 0 and          rable prior assumptions) [17, 19, 309, 310].
peaks at a moderate value of χp that depends on the prior           The in-plane spin components are less well constrained
ranges of χ1 , χ2 and q, and so an inferred nonzero value        than those parallel to the orbital angular momentum.
does not necessarily imply a measurement of precession.          Given the constraint that spin magnitudes cannot ex-
   As a consequence of orbital precession, χp changes            ceed 1, a measurement of χeff influences the permitted
throughout the inspiral. However, the tilt angles of a           values of χp . This constraint means that the χp poste-
compact binary at a formally infinite separation are well        rior probability distribution may appear different from
defined [289]. We thus quote the tilt angles and the             its (unrestricted) prior distribution even in cases where

relative to the orbital plane, marginalized over azimuthal angles, for candidates GW191103 012549, GW191109 010717,
GW191204 171526, GW191219 163120, GW200129 065458 and GW200210 092254, ordered chronologically. BBH waveform
models are used for all the results shown here. GW191103 012549 has χeff = 0.21+0.16     −0.10 with negligible posterior support at
zero. GW191109 010717 has χeff < 0 at 90% probability and χp = 0.63+0.28                                                  +0.08
                                                                              −0.38 . GW191204 171526 has χeff = 0.16−0.05 with
no posterior support at zero. GW191219 163120 is a NSBH candidate with χp ≤ 0.14 at 90% probability; this candidate has
significant uncertainty in its pastro and has significant posterior support outside of mass ratios where the waveform models have
been calibrated. GW200129 065458 has χp = 0.52+0.41    −0.38 . GW200210 092254 has χp ≤ 0.32 at 90% probability and mass ratio
q = 0.118+0.048
          −0.041 . In these plots, histogram bins are constructed linearly in spin magnitude and the cosine of the tilt angles such
that they contain equal prior probability.


homogeneous evolution [332–334]. In this case, predicted                                                                            C.       Tidal effects
BH spins are typically ∼ 0.3–0.5, and may extend up
to the Kerr limit [232, 335]. Spin could also be im-                                                        If a binary contains at least one NS component, the
parted by asymmetric supernova explosions [307]. For                                                     GW signal from the inspiral is influenced by the deforma-
BBHs embedded in active galactic nuclei discs, accre-                                                    bility of NS matter. Tidal effects are quantified by the
tion can grow spins if they are prograde with respect to                                                 dimensionless quadrupole tidal deformability,

tions where it was not possible to determine the nature
of the compact objects from the GW data alone, such as
GW170817 [126, 260] and GW190814 [241].                                      E.   Waveform systematics

Table V. List of candidates tested by BayesWave and cWB for consistency with the waveform templates used in the inference
of source parameters. We quote the on-source match calculated using the waveform reconstructed for the candidate, and the
median and 90% symmetric interval for off-source matches calculated for simulated signals with source parameters consistent
with those inferred for the candidate signal. The values reported in the table correspond to those in Fig. 12. Dashes (–)
correspond to candidates not included in an analysis.


 Here, as in GWTC-2 [3], we measure the waveform               cWB consistency tests are different. For the BayesWave
match (or overlap), defined by                                 analysis we consider candidates that are sufficiently loud
                                                               and short for BayesWave to produce valid signal recon-
                                  ⟨h1 |h2 ⟩                    structions. The candidates considered by cWB are those
             O(h1 , h2 ) = p                        ,   (6)

                                                               plus 5 additional candidates that were identified by other

in Eq. (6) does not depend on the amplitude of each            cWB postproduction cuts that are used to identify low-

duces the match value, and the calculated match does           are reported in Table V.

of 1 indicates a perfect coincidence between waveforms,        ence library Bilby [144, 146] using the IMRPhenomXPHM

on-source match. For each candidate, the match is com-            Figure 13 shows the p-values sorted in increasing or-
puted off source between injected waveforms and their re-      der [109, 380]. When the null hypothesis holds, the sorted
constructions, while on source it is computed between the      p-values are expected to remain close to the median value

likelihood estimate provided by source-parameter estima-       median line shows the size of the fluctuations that we ex-
tion.                                                          pect to observe. Any significant deviations below the plot

                                                            On-source matches                                                                                                                                                 On-source matches


Figure 12. Off-source versus on-source match values for the candidates in O3b. The left and right panels show the results of the
BayesWave and cWB analyses, respectively. The on-source match is estimated comparing the inferred maximum-likelihood CBC
waveform with point estimates from the minimally modeled waveform reconstructions. The off-source match is the median
value of the match distribution estimated from off-source injection of sample waveforms from the template-based posterior
distribution. The error bars in both panels are given by the symmetric (equal-tailed) 90% confidence interval, and they mark
the distance from the null hypothesis (blue dashed line). The different sizes of the error bars in the two panels is due to the
different numbers of off-source injections in the BayesWave and cWB analyses.

                         100                                                                                                                                                             100

Figure 13. Distribution of p-values for the O3b candidates reconstructed by the minimally modeled pipelines. The left and
right panels report the BayesWave and cWB results, respectively. The p-values are sorted in increasing order and graphed
against the order number (blue dashed line). Each p-value is estimated from the observed on-source match value and the related
off-source distribution of the match values from off-source injections. The shadowed orange band is the symmetric 90% interval
about the median, represented by the orange solid line. The blue band represents the symmetric 90% interval associated with
the finite number of off-source injections.
                                                                                                                        41

of candidates that show potential disagreement with the         object physics.
waveform templates. However, the significance of sev-
eral simultaneous deviations cannot be directly assessed           The growing catalog of GW sources has revealed a
from the 90% interval, which is calculated for single val-      diversity of potential CBC sources. Among the candi-
ues [386]. Since the p-values are sorted in increasing or-      dates are a few with posterior support for high spins
der, the sorting induces a correlation between successive       (χi ≳ 0.8) and large mass asymmetries (q ≲ 0.1). Cre-
values, and this means that there may be a whole subset         ating waveform models in these regimes is challenging,
of points outside the interval. All of the 15 cWB p-values      as the need to maintain accuracy necessitates more com-
are within the 90% interval. This is not the case for           plete prescriptions of the underlying physics, including
BayesWave, where it is important to consider the finite-        effects such as spin-induced precession [387, 388] plus
size effect due to the limited number of off-source samples     higher-order multipole moments [178, 357, 362, 374].
in the match distribution. The posterior probability dis-       This task is further complicated by the lack of extensive
tribution for the p-value estimate due to the finite-size ef-   NR waveform catalogs covering these regions of param-
fect is Beta(n+1, N −n+1), where N is the total number          eter space [389–392]. As sensitivity improves, waveform
of samples, and n is the number of samples with a match         uncertainty may be a significant source of systematic un-

of p-values for the null hypothesis, the p-value plots in       ative to develop improved waveform models that cover a

effect: we see that after including this effect there are 4     important additional physics such as orbital eccentric-

do not overlap). Finding 4 incompatible p-values is not
an unlikely event, it has a ∼ 4.1% probability of being due       Data products associated with GWTC-3 results are

the p-value plots indicate that there is no significant in-     detector strain data [399, 400]. Release of previous ob-

nals, focused on the predictions from general relativity,       20, 104, 105, 210, 402–404]. Therefore, we anticipate that
are given in a companion paper [6].                             further discoveries may come from O3b data.

                                                                  O3 saw the Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo de-
                                                                tectors reach their greatest sensitivity to date, enabling
                 VII.    CONCLUSION
                                                                an unprecedented rate of discovery. Coupled to the
                                                                longer duration of O3 compared to previous observing
   We have presented the latest LVK catalog of GWs,             runs, this sensitivity has enabled the number of GW de-
which contains a total of 90 CBC candidate signals              tections from O3 to significantly exceed that from O1 and
with an estimated probability of astrophysical origin           O2. The Advanced LIGO and Advanced Virgo detectors
pastro > 0.5. GWTC-3 builds upon past catalogs of               are currently offline undergoing commissioning to fur-
GW candidates from O1 [13], O2 [14] and O3a [3, 4],             ther enhance their performance for O4. O4 will also see
adding an additional 35 candidates from O3b with                the joint operation of the KAGRA detector [405]. KA-
pastro > 0.5. These include the NSBH candidates                 GRA successfully completed a joint observing run with
GW191219 163120 and GW200115 042309, as well as the             GEO 600 following the end of O3 for Advanced LIGO and
candidate GW200210 092254 that could potentially be             Advanced Virgo [406], and O4 will be the first oppor-
either from a NSBH or a BBH. We additionally provide a          tunity for observations from the LIGO–Virgo–KAGRA
list of candidates with pastro < 0.5 meeting a FAR thresh-      detector network. The enhanced O4 global detector net-
old of < 2.0 day−1 . This includes GW200105 162426,             work will further increase the prospects for GW and mul-
which is estimated to have pastro = 0.36 but is a clear         timessenger discoveries [25].
outlier from our background noise distribution, and is
inferred to have a NSBH source [8]. While we expect                While the 90 probable GW candidates of GWTC-3 all
∼ 4–6 of the candidates with pastro > 0.5 to be false           correspond to CBC sources, we anticipate that there are
alarms, we also expect ∼ 7 candidates with pastro < 0.5         other GW signals waiting to be found [407]. These could
to be astrophysical GW signals. GW observations of              include new types of transient signal, such as from super-
CBCs provide new insight into diverse areas of physics          novae [408], cosmic strings [30], or previously unidenti-
ranging from binary stellar evolution to gravitation. Fur-      fied sources [31, 32]. Additionally, we may find long-lived
ther analysis and interpretation of the GWTC-3 candi-           signals such as continuous waves from rotating NSs [409–
dates is conducted in the companion papers [5–7]. As the        414] or stochastic backgrounds [415, 416]. As detector
population of GW observations grows, it will be possible        sensitivity increases and we observe for longer, we expect
to make increasingly detailed measurements of compact-          more of the GW universe to reveal itself.

                                                              candidate. The preliminary alerts were typically issued
   Public alerts were issued for GW candidates identi-        within a few minutes of data collection, for which latency
fied by low-latency searches of the data. These can-          due to data transfer between sites and search investiga-
didates were cataloged in the Gravitational Candidate         tion were largely dominated by the GWCelery task. The
Event Database (GraceDB). Each entry into GraceDB             human vetting and delivery of initial alerts had a median

specific time window is referred to as a superevent. The         There were 40 public alerts sent out via GCN during

spread of events, with a typical value of 1 s symmetric       23 from O3b were not retracted; the remaining were re-
around the merger time. The duration of the time win-         tracted on timescales from minutes to days. The major-
dow for cWB was variable and was reported by the search       ity of the retracted public alerts in O3b corresponded to
pipeline for each event. One candidate event belonging        candidates with SNR ρ > 5 in only one detector. The
to the superevent was identified as the preferred event,      online search pipelines collect background in real time,
and its attributes (time, localization, significance, clas-   leaving them susceptible to new noise sources, and single-

by the superevent. The HasRemnant property indicator          ties in the background noise distribution since they can-

Table VI. Public alerts and follow-up investigations of O3a GW candidates. The columns show the superevent identification
(SID), the GW candidate name if in offline results [3, 4], the GCN Circular, and references for follow-up publications. Candidates
retracted following rapid event-validation checks are marked in italics. Candidates without superevent identifications were found
only in the offline searches.

Table VII. Public alerts and follow-up investigations of O3b GW candidates. The columns show the superevent identification
(SID), the GW candidate name if in the offline results (including GW200105 162426), the GCN Circular, and references for
follow-up publications. Candidates retracted following rapid event-validation checks are marked in italics. Candidates without
superevent identifications were found only in the offline searches.

results. The O3 candidates were predominantly BBHs,                            10−21

   The neutrino follow-up involved searches of events with
energies ranging from ∼ 1 MeV to ∼ 1 PeV. No con-
firmed neutrino counterpart has been found for any GW                          10−23
candidate [437–442, 449, 457, 459, 587].
   The gamma and X-ray observations involved energies                          10−24
extending up to ∼ 1 TeV. The majority of high-energy                                   10               100                    1000

Table VIII. Summary of selected optical and physical parameters of the LIGO Hanford (H), LIGO Livingston (L), and Virgo
(V) interferometers in the advanced-detector era. The input laser power is an estimate for the maximum laser power level
typically achieved during the observing period, and is the power that would be measured at the power recycling mirror (after
the input mode cleaner). The suspension type is abbreviated to Silica for monolithic fused-silica fibers, and Steel for steel
wires.

Table IX. Top: Data-quality products used for noise mitigation by each offline search pipeline. Products listed here are publicly
available from GWOSC [33]. Most analyses employ additional internal noise mitigation methods, including gating [79, 83, 93,
110, 611]. Bottom: The percent of single-detector time removed by each of the same veto categories for each detector during
O3b. Veto time values for LIGO Hanford and LIGO Livingston are reproduced from studies of O3 detector characterization [63].
A dash (–) in a data-quality product’s column indicates that it is not produced for the relevant detector, except for iDQ output;
iDQ has no associated removed time as it is incorporated directly into the search-pipeline ranking statistic [612]. The listed
removed time is in addition to the downtime associated with one or more detectors not being in a nominal observing state, as
described in Sec. II, which is common to all searches.


during O3 for LIGO and Virgo [614, 615]. Category 1               tic to penalize triggers near periods of high iDQ likeli-

Table X. State information and data-quality products used for noise mitigation by each online search pipeline. For each
detector, the state vector defines the times the detector is online and the data is ready for analysis. The LIGO Data Quality
vector and Virgo online Category 1 products flag known instrument artifacts during observing mode [63, 616]. Information
from online data-quality products is available in a different form for offline searches, e.g., the Category 1 and Category 2
data-quality products, as part of the products listed in Table IX. Most analyses employ additional internal noise mitigation
methods, including gating [79, 83, 93, 110, 611].


number of model components (wavelets, spectral lines                                                             Normalized energy
and spline control points for the smooth portion of the                                    0.0       2.5         5.0    7.5    10.0      12.5   15.0
PSD) is allowed to vary, in addition to the parameters
that describe each component.

   The signal model reconstructs the plus and cross po-
                                                                                      60         Original data
larization states of a GW signal as a sum of wavelets,
which are coherently projected onto the detector net-                                 40
work [379]. We use the waveform reconstruction pro-                                   30




                                                                    Frequency [Hz]
duced by BayesWave in the waveform consistency tests                                  20
as discussed in Sec. VI. The glitch model reconstructs
noise transients separately in each detector. The spec-                               10
tral model adjusts to take into account the power that                               100
gets assigned to the signal and glitch models. Central                                60         Subtracted data
to the BayesWave approach is that the model dimension
                                                                                      40
is not fixed, with both the number of wavelets and their                              30
parameters explored using a transdimensional reversible                               20
jump Markov-chain Monte Carlo algorithm [618]. Louder
signals generally demand more wavelets. In the case of                                10
CBC signals, high-mass, short-duration signals are gen-                                 −20                −10          0         10            20
erally reconstructed with fewer wavelets than low-mass,                                                              Time [s]
longer-duration signals.
   The natural parsimony of Bayesian inference works to
ensure that any coherent signal power is assigned to the
signal model, while any incoherent noise transients are           Figure 15.    A spectrogram [73] of LIGO Livingston data

data in each detector independently. Thus, this method

   The mitigated data discussed in Appendix E 1 for                  In order to assess the efficacy of glitch subtraction by

compared the stationarity of the glitch-subtracted data       SNR loss due to the templates not exactly matching the
within the targeted time–frequency window to Gaussian         signals is acceptable while keeping the total number of
noise. Glitch-subtracted data consistent with Gaussian        templates small enough to be computationally feasible.
noise were deemed sufficiently stationary for parameter       The minimum match is dependent on the region of the
estimation.                                                   parameter space, but is never smaller than 0.97 [3].
   Uncertainties related to the glitch modeling are not          Triggers are defined by maximizing the matched-filter

   The GstLAL pipeline [78–81, 623, 624] uses matched         in the signal hypothesis of finding the given observables

                        5.   cWB                              signal has a peak frequency inversely proportional to the
                                                              redshifted total mass, so that less massive binary systems
   The cWB pipeline detects and reconstructs transient        merge at higher frequencies, while more massive systems
signals with minimal assumptions [60, 89, 107–109] by         merge at lower frequencies. Therefore, just as for the
coherently analyzing data from multiple observatories.        GWTC-2 analysis [3], the cWB analyses in this catalog
The sensitivity of cWB approaches that of matched-filter      are performed with two pipeline configurations targeting
methods for coalescing stellar-mass BBHs with high chirp      the detection of high-mass (fc < 80 Hz) and low-mass
masses [26, 656], such that it can detect high-mass CBC       (fc > 80 Hz) BBH systems. These configurations use
sources, and also sources that are not well represented       different signal-dependent vetoes defined a priori to alle-
in current template banks such as eccentric systems or        viate the large variability of nonstationary noise in the

was used in previous CBC searches by the LVK [3, 12,             We estimate the FAR of triggers by time shifting the
14, 657].                                                     data of one detector with respect to the other in each
   The cWB algorithm analyzes whitened data using the         detector pair, with time lags so large (typically multiples
Wilson–Daubechies–Meyer wavelet transform [89, 108] to        of 1 s) that actual astrophysical signals are excluded, and
compute a time–frequency representation. The algorithm        repeating this for a large number of different time lags
selects excess-energy data in the time–frequency repre-       over a total time Tbkg which is of the order of 103 yr. We
sentation and clusters them to define a trigger. Next,        count the number of triggers Nbkg due to background
it identifies coherent signal power with the constrained      noise having a SNR (or another similar ranking statistic)
maximum-likelihood method [60], and reconstructs the          that is at least as large as that of the trigger, and we
source sky location and the signal waveforms.                 compute the FAR as the Nbkg divided by Tbkg [660].

are indicated by H, L and V, respectively. Numbers in italics indicate where a candidate is identified with probability of
astrophysical origin pastro < 0.5. Dashes (–) indicate where no significant trigger was identified by a search analysis.

Table XII. Parameter distributions used to generate injections and to compute the probability of astrophysical origin pastro
for each pipeline. The BNS injections are generated using the SpinTaylorT4 waveform model [631, 632, 634, 636–640], while
the BBH and NSBH injections are generated using the SEOBNRv4PHM model [137], or the SEOBNRv4P model [137, 625, 662] for
injections corresponding to binaries with redshifted total mass below 9M⊙ . We always use the convention that m1 ≥ m2 ; this
constraint means that the marginalized one-dimensional distributions for the masses will not match the distributions used to
define the two-dimensional distributions (as given here) in cases where the m1 and m2 distributions overlap. Masses are in the
source frame, except for the PyCBC rows, where the measured (redshifted) chirp mass is considered. The redshift-evolution
parameter κ controls the injected distribution as described in Eq. (D1). The injection sets are used to estimate sensitive
hypervolumes, with weights to match the populations assumed within each ⟨V T ⟩ calculation, including updating the mass,
spin, and redshift distributions where appropriate.

Table XIII. Multicomponent pastro values for candidates with pastro > 0.5 and marginal candidates with FAR < 2.0 yr−1
where the probability of a BNS or NSBH category is nonzero in any search analysis. Since cWB does not calculate separate
source probabilities, all sources are treated as BBHs for the purposes of pastro calculation. Results in italics indicate where an
analysis found the candidate with pastro < 0.5, and a dash (–) indicates that a candidate was not found by an analysis. Source
probability for BNS is not given for PyCBC-BBH, as the search is not sensitive to redshifted chirp masses below 4.353M⊙ .
This would require extremely high redshifts, to which LIGO and Virgo are not sensitive, to correspond to a BNS source. The
BNS, NSBH and BBH categories are defined by the masses associated with the candidate from the search results (as defined
in Table XII), and do not necessarily correspond to the true astrophysical population of sources.

Table XIV. Sensitive hypervolume ⟨V T ⟩ for the various search analyses for all of O3 at the assessed points in the mass
parameter space. The Any results come from calculating the sensitive hypervolume for injections found by at least one search
analysis. The sets of binary masses and distribution of injections found in this bin are the same as given in Table III. As
in Table III, where insufficient numbers of injections are recovered such that the sensitive hypervolume cannot be accurately
estimated; these cases are indicated by a dash (–).

Table XV. Updated probability of astrophysical origin pastro , FAR and SNR values for candidates from O3a using data from
the whole of O3. We include pastro values for any candidates that were published in GWTC-2.1 [4] with pastro > 0.5. Using all
of the O3 data, there are no changes to the list of candidates with pastro > 0.5. As in Table I, results in italics indicate where
an analysis found the candidate with pastro < 0.5, and a dash (–) indicates that a candidate was not found by an analysis.
Although cWB contributed to the analysis of GW190814 [241], it is not included in the cWB column because it was not detected
with LV alone with the standard data-quality vetoes, but required a manual override of the LIGO Hanford vetoes. This table
updates Table I of GWTC-2.1 [4].

Table XVI. List of data used and mitigation methods applied to data surrounding each candidate prior to source-parameter
estimation. We list the candidates for which we performed mitigation of instrumental artifacts; there are 7 candidates reported
in Table I and the previously reported GW200105 162426 [8]. For all analyses using Virgo data, calibration error at ∼ 50 Hz
was mitigated by notching out the relevant frequency range. The noise-subtraction methods (BayesWave [377, 379] glitch
modeling and gwsubtract linear subtraction using a witness [44, 59]) used for these candidates are detailed in Appendix C.

code. This allowed the creation of analysis pipeline con-      durations [109, 657]. However, we find that the three
figurations to be fully automated, with the intention of       candidates have a range of signal morphologies.

differences in waveforms used. However, there do exist a       series of glitches in the LIGO Livingston detector. The
number of differences between the analyses, such as the        time around these glitches was vetoed by a Burst Cat-
marginalization over time and the tapering applied to          egory 2 flag that measured length sensing and control

results. Any differences should be negligible for intrinsic    served at other times for both the LIGO Livingston and
parameters such as the masses. In cases where the Bilby        LIGO Hanford detectors [695]. In O3, it was observed
and RIFT parameters agree, we can be more confident            that times around these loud glitches produced a higher

                                                                  The candidate 190930 234652 was identified in low la-
  Appendix F: Unconfirmed cWB-only candidates                  tency by the cWB BBH search analyzing HL network
                                                               data, and in the offline analysis its SNR is 8.6 and FAR
  The minimally modeled cWB pipeline (described in             is 1.0 yr−1 . Slow scattering glitches [69] are present in
Sec. IV B) can identify a range of signal morphologies,        the LIGO Hanford data at the time of the candidate.
including signals unrelated to CBC sources [31]. Since         These glitches correlate with the observed motion of the
cWB does not exploit the rich prior information provided       suspension systems and directly overlap the candidate.
by CBC waveform templates, its flexibility in identifying      At LIGO Livingston, excess motion was measured by ac-
many potential signals comes with a reduced sensitivity        celerometers at the time of the candidate that may also

                                                                                                                                          65

We consider this candidate of likely instrumental origin.
   The candidate 200214 224526 was identified in low la-                                                Normalized energy
tency by the cWB BBH search analyzing HL network                                       0.0   2.5        5.0    7.5    10.0       12.5   15.0
data, and in the offline analysis its SNR is 13.1 and
FAR is 0.13 yr−1 . In LIGO Livingston, the candidate
was associated with a fast scattering glitch [69]; a se-                                                                190804 083543
quence of such glitches is observed for multiple seconds
before and after the candidate. As shown in Fig. 16,                             100
the glitch overlaps the candidate in LIGO Livingston. In
LIGO Hanford, we find evidence of a weak scattering arch
that started ∼ 0.5 s before the trigger and lasted ∼ 2 s in
the frequency range 20–30 Hz. The candidate was stud-                             10
ied in the search for IMBH binaries [26], where it was
listed as the third-ranked candidate (the first ranked be-
                                                                                                                        190930 234652



                                                                Frequency [Hz]
ing GW190521). However, it was not corroborated by
any matched-filter search analysis, and it was concluded
                                                                                 100
that the trigger was due to noise.
   For each of 190804 083543, 190930 234652 and
200214 224526 there is plausible evidence that the candi-
date is of instrumental origin. Regardless of the instru-
mental or astrophysical origin of these candidates, their                         10
morphologies (as shown in Fig. 17) do not resemble the
CBC signals so far detected. The versatility of cWB in                                                                  200214 224526
identifying potential signals without a template means
that a variety of sources could be detected, such that the                       100
assumption of a CBC source is not assured and must be
verified. Under the alternative assumption of a non-CBC
source, the probability of astrophysical origin would be
reduced, making any candidates less plausible as GW                               10
signals. Detection of new source types, and inference of                               −2          −1           0            1           2
their rates, would enable calculation of pastro for a range                                                  Time [s]
of sources in addition to CBCs.

                                                              Figure 16.         Spectrograms [73] of data surrounding
                                                              190804 083543, 190930 234652 and 200214 224526. Time is
                                                              plotted relative to the central time of each trigger. The plot-
                                                              ted data are from LIGO Hanford for 190930 234652 and from
                                                              LIGO Livingston for 190804 083543 and 200214 224526. The
                                                              red box represents the bandwidth and duration of the can-
                                                              didate identified by cWB. In all three cases, the data are
                                                              affected by transient noise at the time of the trigger, and
                                                              additional excess power is present in the data that is not ac-
                                                              counted for as part of the trigger identified by cWB. Although
                                                              there is power present in the other detectors, the evidence for
                                                              instrumental origin of the candidate in one detector makes it
                                                              likely that this is just a chance coincidence.

and for 200214 224526, the offset is 1265755544 s.
